Dialogue:
ES: Hello!
CD: Hello!
ES: What did you eat for lunch?
CD: I ate pasta!
ES: Pasta sounds good. Did you make it at home?
CD: Yes, with tomato sauce.
ES: Was the sauce handmade too?
CD: I bought the sauce and added anchovies.
ES: Anchovies are uncommon to have at home, aren't they?
CD: I recently bought some. Do you like anchovies?
ES: I don’t remember eating them much. Are they fish?
CD: Yes, it's a paste made from sardines or something similar.
ES: Are they sold in the pasta section?
CD: Yes, usually around there.
ES: What does it taste like? It seems unique.
CD: It tastes like fish.
ES: I’m curious. I’ll check it out next time I go to the supermarket.
CD: Yes. What did you eat?
ES: I had curry.
CD: Did you make it at home?
ES: Yes, I had frozen rice and instant curry.
CD: Retort curries from Muji are delicious, aren't they?
ES: I like them too. What's your favorite?
CD: Butter chicken curry is a safe choice.
ES: A classic. Do you handle spicy food well?
CD: Yes, I do.
ES: I also enjoy spicy food, so I usually get green curry.
CD: Is it very spicy?
ES: Yes, it is.
CD: That might be too spicy for me.

ES: Hello.  
CD: Hello.  
ES: Do you usually listen to music?  
CD: I listen! I'm listening now.  
ES: That's interesting! What kind of music do you like?  
CD: I was listening to the song "Just Look Up" by Ariana Grande.  
ES: Foreign music is nice! But I've never heard that song before.  
CD: Do you know the movie called "Look Up"?  
ES: That's new to me. Is it recent?  
CD: Is it this year's movie? It's on Netflix, but it's that song.  
ES: The song is new too, I'll listen to it on YouTube later.  
CD: Movies are also recommended! Do you listen to Western music?  
ES: I do! I liked Fifth Harmony during their peak.  
CD: Is it when there are five people?  
ES: That's right, one member left, and their momentum slowed down.  
CD: Camilla, right? I liked her too.  
ES: Exactly! Are you knowledgeable about Western music?  
CD: I only listen to Western music. So when I go to karaoke, it's full of songs I don't know.  
ES: I see, who is your favorite singer besides Ariana-chan?  
CD: I mostly listen to the classics. Taylor and Justin, for example.  
ES: Nice, I used to listen to Justin's old songs often.  
CD: I feel like we might be around the same age!  
ES: I feel that way! I love "Beauty and the Beast," which collaborated with Nicki Minaj!  
CD: That's great! Let's get into the groove!  
ES: Even now, I can still get really into it, but it's quite an old song, isn't it?  
CD: Yes. Justin looked really young in the music video.  
ES: I can't believe I could get so excited talking with someone so knowledgeable!  
CD: Yes! That time when Justin had bangs. Haha.  
ES: I miss the time when he was so cute.  
CD: That's right! Thank you for the conversation!

ES: Hello.
AR: Hello. Please let me know how I can assist you today.
ES: I'm feeling a bit nervous.
AR: Do you often feel nervous around new people?
ES: Yes, I do get quite anxious.
AR: I can relate. I manage fine with initial meetings, but I tend to get nervous during important events.
ES: I think that's similar to me! By "important events," do you mean presentations?
AR: Yes, that's correct. I don't do it much now, but when I was younger, I used to write the character for "people" (人) on my palm.
ES: That brings back memories!
AR: It seems to be a common practice, right?
ES: I don't remember where I learned it, but I did it too! Also, imagining the audience as potatoes helps.
AR: That's another nostalgic method. It's nice when conversations match shared experiences.
ES: I agree! I wonder if kids today still do things like writing 人人人.
AR: My children are still quite young at 6 and 5 years old, so they don't understand it yet. It would be nice if they did those gestures when they grow older.
ES: Your children are quite young! It would be wonderful if you could teach them.
AR: We currently play games like Alpus Ichiman Shaku and Glico Pineapple Chocolate. It's fun to play together.
ES: Those games are timeless and enjoyable! Do you play outside?
AR: Yes, they prefer being outside, especially with all the extra energy since the coronavirus pandemic.
ES: A friend of mine also mentioned that raising a boy can be challenging due to their high energy levels.
AR: I notice a big difference when I see my child's female classmates; they are usually more calm, drawing or playing house.
ES: There's certainly a noticeable difference in how boys and girls play.
AR: I'd like to try matching outfits with a girl someday. Boys can be quite affectionate too.
ES: Is your child also quite affectionate?
AR: Girls seem more direct with their feelings. Sometimes, they still want to be held.
ES: I see! Being affectionate is indeed adorable.
AR: It definitely brings out my nurturing instincts. I'm sure fathers find their daughters equally charming.
ES: It seems common for mothers to bond well with sons and fathers with daughters. Kids are indeed wonderful.
AR: Their innocence feels refreshing, and it's as if I'm being cleansed. I don't want them to grow up too fast!
ES: The purity of children is truly special.
AR: It is invaluable! See you next time!

ES: Hello.
EV: Hello, how can I assist you today?
ES: What did you have for lunch?
EV: Cold udon noodles.
ES: Were they frozen?
EV: No, I boiled them and then cooled them down.
ES: How did they taste? Did you use noodle soup base?
EV: Yes, with mentsuyu.
ES: I've been trying different udon flavors recently.
EV: Udon has many variations.
ES: True. Besides noodle soup base, what other flavors do you like?
EV: Egg and green onion.
ES: Simple can be really nice.
EV: I also use soy sauce sometimes.
ES: Soy sauce adds a different taste. I've been adding rice cakes.
EV: Udon with mochi? Like ozoni soup?
ES: Yes, sometimes with miso flavor.
EV: Understood.
ES: It is, especially with gochujang or doubanjiang.
EV: Sounds interesting.
ES: Do you lose your appetite in the summer?
EV: Yes, I often feel fatigued.
ES: I feel the same. I'm trying to be creative with meals.
EV: Spicy food can help.
ES: Do you like spicy food?
EV: I can handle medium spicy.
ES: Too much spice tends to upset my stomach.
EV: Understood.

ES: Hello!  
EV: Hello, how can I assist you today?  
ES: What do you usually do during this time?  
EV: I usually play games or read manga on holidays.  
ES: That sounds relaxing! What kind of games do you play?  
EV: I play hunting games and RPGs on the PS4.  
ES: Do you play games on your smartphone?  
EV: Yes, I play baseball and Dragon Ball games.  
ES: There's a baseball game on smartphones? I'd like to try it!  
EV: Yes, it’s a good way to pass the time.  
ES: What is the name of the game?  
EV: It's called Prospi. For a more casual experience, PowerPro might be better.  
ES: Is it a game where you use actual athletes as characters?  
EV: Yes, it's often featured in commercials.  
ES: Do you like baseball?  
EV: Yes, I watch it sometimes.  
ES: Do you have a favorite team?  
EV: I don’t have a favorite team. I enjoy watching close games.  
ES: I want to watch a Nippon-Ham Fighters game.  
EV: My home is in Hokkaido, so it’s far unless they’re playing away.  
ES: Is there a stadium nearby?  
EV: Since I’m in Tokyo, I can go to the Dome.  
ES: It's nice that the Dome isn't affected by the weather.  
EV: Have you watched a game live?  
ES: About 10 years ago.  
ES: Is it different from watching on TV?  
EV: Yes, the cheering squad enhances the excitement.  
ES: The atmosphere must be amazing.  
EV: Yes, but I don’t understand much about pitches.

ES: Nice to meet you, please take care of me.  
EV: Nice to meet you. Thank you.  
ES: Have you been on any trips recently?  
EV: I won't be traveling due to the current situation.  
ES: It's quite difficult to go, isn't it?  
EV: Yes, I planned to visit my parents, but it got canceled.  
ES: Is it because COVID-19 is spreading again?  
EV: Yes, my mother contracted COVID.  
ES: Is your mother okay?  
EV: Yes, her treatment is finished, but it was stressful.  
ES: I see. There are people around me who have lingering aftereffects.  
EV: Since my mother works at a hospital, it's a risk she faces daily.  
ES: In this day and age, I admire that you are working at a hospital.  
EV: Yes, it's been challenging. It has started to increase again.  
ES: Didn't your family get disappointed when you canceled your trip home?  
EV: No, we understand the necessity. We can't enter the house safely.  
ES: I see, it would be nice if you could visit your hometown again.  
EV: I hope to return in the winter if the situation improves.  
ES: Do you remember what the infection situation was like last winter?  
EV: It was common. I stayed at a hotel to monitor my health.  
ES: There are a lot of things to be considerate about, aren't there?  
EV: Yes, it calmed down in spring but is back again now.  
ES: The situation remains one where we cannot let our guard down recently.  
EV: Traveling isn't bad, but risks increase if you get too excited.  
ES: After all, when you go back to your hometown or travel, you want to go out, don't you?  
EV: Yes, it would be a waste otherwise, but we need to be careful.  
ES: I understand the feeling of wanting to have fun if you're going to do it anyway.  
EV: We have to endure it for a while. Let's take care of our health.  
ES: Let's take care of our health!  
EV: Yes, thank you very much.

ES: Hello!
DN: Hello. Nice to meet you.
ES: Have you decided on tonight's dinner?
DN: No, I haven't decided yet. Have you already decided?
ES: Not yet. I bought pork yesterday.
DN: Is it pork belly?
ES: It's thinly sliced peach meat.
DN: Is it hard to plan the menu?
ES: Yes, I find it confusing. How do you decide?
DN: I often eat items bought during evening sales just as they are.
ES: Is it cheaper in the evening?
DN: Yes, especially fish and sashimi are often less than half price.
ES: That's great! Do you cook them right away?
DN: I usually just arrange them rather than cook.
ES: Like grilling meat?
DN: Yes. I buy sauce for vegetables to make a simple dish.
ES: Is it available in the seasoning section?
DN: It's in retort pouches in the curry and Chinese food section.
ES: I'll check it next time. What else do you use?
DN: Use pasta sauce to cook meat and vegetables.
ES: What flavor do you use?
DN: For tomato sauce, add chicken or minced meat with vegetables.
ES: Minced meat cooks quickly!
DN: Yes. I dilute clam vongole sauce with water, add potatoes, and make soup.
ES: That sounds like a delicious Western-style soup!
DN: Yes. Adding sale items like white fish, clams, and mushrooms makes it very tasty.
ES: Is the white fish used as it is?
DN: It's mostly processed, so it's used as it is.
ES: I've struggled with fish recipes. This is helpful!
DN: Pasta sauce is convenient!

ES: Hello, nice to meet you.  
DN: Hello. Nice to meet you.  
ES: Have you been on a trip recently?  
DN: No, I went outside the prefecture, but I didn't go on a trip.  
ES: I see, it's quite a difficult time to go out, isn't it?  
DN: Yes. However, on weekends, I sometimes take the express bus to visit my son in Kansai.  
ES: So you’re in the Kansai region?  
DN: No. I travel from Aichi Prefecture to Osaka and Kobe.  
ES: I see. I'm in Tokyo now, but I’d like to visit Aichi and Osaka someday.  
DN: My other son is in Kanagawa, and I sometimes take the bus there too.  
ES: Do you like bus trips?  
DN: The Shinkansen is expensive, but the bus is quite a bargain.  
ES: It doesn't cost even half as much as the Shinkansen, does it?  
DN: There are high-speed buses with capsule seats between Aichi, Osaka, and Tokyo.  
ES: Is it completely private?  
DN: The capsule is shaped so you can stretch your legs and offers privacy.  
ES: That is very intriguing and seems private as well.  
DN: Yes. I choose a three-row seat when traveling between Aichi and Tokyo, but the capsule is better.  
ES: Are all three rows capsules?  
DN: Yes. This bus has only 17 seats, all capsules.  
ES: There are few seats, aren't there? Is there a restroom on the bus?  
DN: This company’s buses don’t have running restrooms.  
ES: Is there a bathroom break along the way?  
DN: There are 3 breaks. The lights are off on the midnight bus, with breaks before midnight and around 5 AM.  
ES: In that case, it's manageable! You can enjoy the journey without much worry.  
DN: Yes. Recently, rest areas have been well-equipped. I played a public piano at the Hamamatsu SA.  
ES: Like the town piano program on NHK?  
DN: Yes, it’s been popular lately.  
ES: Have you appeared on that show?  
DN: No, I just play and then leave!
